advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Alice, a computer for all levels"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1986 price list:<br> Monochrome - Single drive: <b>£399</b> + VAT<br> Monochrome - Dual drive: <b>£499</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Single drive: <b>£549</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Dual drive: <b>£649</b> + VAT<br><br> Optional 10 MB hard disk: <b>£300</b> + VAT </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISPLAY SIZE ARGUMENT CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Osborne 1 was the major competitor of the KAYCOMP in the portable computers field.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD !</strong></font><br><blockquote>This authentic picture show a proud owner of a Wren transportable computer ! It looks like it bought it 5 minutes ago as he doesn't really know from which side to handle it...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to datareign.co.uk for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> We know your question: How could Olivetti have developped a better personal computer than the other giants?<br> The answer is in a word: Experience. Olivetti introduced the world's first desktop computer in 1965. Since then, we've continued to market a variety of minicomputers and microcomputers to a wide range of users...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"List your technical requirements, Hewlett-Packard is ready to answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thomson, the micro capital"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT. #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>I love this advert ! Their pullovers are so... colored.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The high performance Computer System for practice-oriented applications." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ABORTED ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the aborted advert campaigns for the 8048 was "Micromania".<p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD (SEPT. 87)</strong></font><br><blockquote>It is unlikely that this hideous advert helped early sales of the Archimedes.<br> It said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Acorn are proud to announce the fastest micros in the world * The Archimedes high performance Computer Systems * Using a 32 bit RISC chip, Archimedes represents a breakthrough in microprocessing technology allowing a new order of magnitude in power...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Preliminary/New product leaflet. For exhibitions only<br><br><br> "The new Personal Computer from SHARP - particularly developed for personal use."<br><br> Note the optional Quick Disc drive.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRONG WOOMAN(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Don't beleive this advert!<br> Please, look carefully at the quite horizontal shoulders of the woman who carries the Osborne (about 12 Kg). Either she is a champion of wrestling, or the Osborne case is empty. <br><br> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DECEMBER 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 12 years old, Nicolas discovered he was the terror of the aliens"</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: None, mostly used with COMAL 80 or PASCAL.
computer.description:
The Piccoline is a direct descendant of the Piccolo, and was launched in 1984.
It was more or less strictly meant for Danish educational institutions such as schools, high schools and universities. It was used extensively for teaching basic programming skills, using the languages Comal 80 and Pascal.
Thanks to Henrik Schmidt from Denmark for information and pictures.
computer.keyboard: Full size QWERTY with Danish characters
computer.language: None, mostly used with COMAL 80 or PASCAL.
computer.media: 5 1/4 ''diskette station with printer interface, sharable between 4 computers
computer.name: RC759 Piccoline
computer.ports: Printer, monitor, cassette player, remote printer/diskette, optional LAN

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> CPU & DISPLAY PROCESSOR</strong></font><br><blockquote>Intel 80186 6 MHz CPU and Intel 82730 Text coprocessor which supports text and graphics displays.</blockquote>
